sentences: Juan Fernando Fonseca was born on May 29, 1979, in Bogotá.

section: == Life and career == | === 1979–1996: Early life ===

sentences: After graduation from college, he recorded his first album titled Bomba de Tiempo that he sold door-to-door, showing the album to patrons at small bars, and eventually selling 500 copies.
section: == Life and career == | === 1997–2007: Debut album and Corazón ===

sentences: Fonseca was searching for a record label when he found the Colombian musician José Gaviria and helped him in an initial recording with Sonolux in United States in 1997.
section: == Life and career == | === 1997–2007: Debut album and Corazón ===

sentences: The project stayed up in the air until 2002 when he signed with Líderes Entertainment Group, a label of EMI Capitol to produce his three upcoming albums.
section: == Life and career == | === 1997–2007: Debut album and Corazón ===

sentences: Fonseca's self-titled debut album was released in February 2002 in Colombia and on December 26, 2005, internationally.
section: == Life and career == | === 1997–2007: Debut album and Corazón ===

sentences: The album had a moderate success in his native country.
section: == Life and career == | === 1997–2007: Debut album and Corazón ===

sentences: The album spawned four singles, "Mangangué", "Noche de Carnaval", "Sueño" and "Confiésame".
section: == Life and career == | === 1997–2007: Debut album and Corazón ===

sentences: The album is highly influenced by the Colombian "tropipop" sound associated with Carlos Vives' albums Clásicos de la Provincia and La Tierra del Olvido.
section: == Life and career == | === 1997–2007: Debut album and Corazón ===

sentences: The album gained him considerable attention in Colombia, including the notice of artists like Shakira and Juanes, both of whom offered him subsequent collaboration and performance opportunities.
section: == Life and career == | === 1997–2007: Debut album and Corazón ===

sentences: Sharing the stage with Shakira on her Tour of the Mongoose and Juanes at Estadio El Campín in Bogota garnered Fonseca the recognition and momentum he would need for his second album.
section: == Life and career == | === 1997–2007: Debut album and Corazón ===

sentences: His second studio album, Corazón produced by Fonseca himself, Bernardo Ossa and the executive producer Alvaro Rizo, was released on May 23, 2006.

sentences: Allmusic gave the album a rating of three out of five stars.

== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: "Fonseca is also very concerned with changing the rest of the world’s view of his mother country, Colombia, using his music as a platform to publicize the positive aspects of the nation" During his U.S. tour in early 2013, Fonseca made a point to show videos of and to speak personally about Colombia.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On the same tour Fonseca worked with Marca Colombia, ("Brand Colombia" in English) a program run by the Colombian government to re-educate other countries about Colombian culture, as well as with the Colombian airline Avianca, a sponsor of the tour.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Of his work with these two entities, Fonseca has said to Colombia Reports, "I am excited that on my Illusion World Tour I will carry the message of Colombia from the Brand Colombia [markets a positive image of the country] to the United States.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: I am very proud of my country and I'm honored to be its ambassador".
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Fonseca states that he views music as a representation of culture, so using his music to promote and educate people on Colombia makes sense to him.
section: == Personal life ==
